block.p: Julia Elizabeth Phelan, the daughter of Mary F. Phelan of Washington, and John J. Phelan of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Benjamin Philip Sylla, the son of Mary Eloise Sylla and Philip M. Sylla of Portland, Ore. Msgr. Charles V. Antonicelli performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Joseph's on Capitol Hill in Washington.

The bride and bridegroom work at the Academy for Educational Development, a nongovernmental organization in Washington that places students from the Middle East, South Asia and North Africa in scholarship programs in the United States financed by the State Department.

Julia Elizabeth Phelan, the daughter of Mary F. Phelan of Washington, and John J. Phelan of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Benjamin Philip Sylla, the son of Mary Eloise Sylla and Philip M. Sylla of Portland, Ore. Msgr. Charles V. Antonicelli performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Josephâ€™s on Capitol Hill in Washington.

Julia Elizabeth Phelan, the daughter of Mary F. Phelan of Washington, and John J. Phelan of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Benjamin Philip Sylla, the son of Mary Eloise Sylla and Philip M. Sylla of Portland, Ore. Msgr. Charles V. Antonicelli performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Joseph's on Capitol Hill in Washington.

The bride and bridegroom work at the Academy for Educational Development, a nongovernmental organization in Washington that places students from the Middle East, South Asia and North Africa in scholarship programs in the United States financed by the State Department.

Mrs. Sylla, 27, is a program officer in international academic partnerships and exchange programs and Mr. Sylla, 28, is a researcher in international education policy for the academy's Education Policy and Data Center.
The bride graduated magna cum laude from Bates College and has a master's degree in international education from George Washington University. She is also a violinist with the Capital City Symphony.

Her father is an associate professor of economics at the University of New Haven. Her mother is a librarian for the District of Columbia Public Library. She was the registrar of collections for the Senate Commission on Art until 1990.
The bridegroom graduated from the University of Virginia and has a master's degree in public policy at George Washington University.

His mother retired last year as a second-grade teacher at the QSI International School of Bratislava in Slovakia. His father was the director of the QSI International School of Bratislava until 2006. This month he will become the head of school at the International School in Portland.
